info.name: DA-Marketplace
info.description:
DA Marketplace is an open-source example of an application written in [Daml](https://daml.com/), that allows for the setup of a configurable Market-in-a-box. The application covers workflows for issuing assets, conducting auctions, listing market pairs, trading, and settlement.

The source repository is [here](https://github.com/digital-asset/da-marketplace) which provides information on how to build and run the application both locally and on [Daml Hub](https://hub.daml.com).

This Postman Collection is the set of API's that can be called via the HTTP JSON API server. 

Please note the following points : 
1. this Postman Collection is not designed to be ran in its entirety in Postman; but as documentation for the various API's exposed by the DA Marketplace application.
2. the API is subject to change. Currently, this document describes the API's of the Marketplace repo with the tag `da-marketplace-v0.2.0-rc.3`.

item.name: Ledger Initialisation - Local

exec: // On a clean ledger on production, we'd need to add a user manually to the ledger and use it in order to create the other users.
// Note - As the first call to an empty ledger, the sandbox will implicitly allocate the party provided inside token.

request.description:
Allocate a new Party on the ledger. 

See [here](https://docs.daml.com/json-api/index.html#allocate-a-new-party) for more details.

exec: // Replace characters according to base64url specifications
console.log('Signed and encoded JWT for party ' + party, signedToken)

item.name: Ledger Initialisation - Hub

request.description:
Acquires your JWT token from Daml Hub.

This call requires : 
1. The ledger id set as a query param;
2. Your Daml Hub Session token set as a cookie.

This token is necessary to request a token for a specific party token and ledger.

header.value: private, no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, no-transform,private, no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, no-transform

request.description:
A read-only public token which can be acquired by any user in order to preform read-only actions against a specific the ledger.

See [here](https://hub.daml.com/docs/api/iam/#post-apiprojectdablcomapiledgerledgeridpublictoken) for more details.
A token which represents your rights on a specific ledger.

Acquires the access token of a specified party on a ledger. 

Requires that the requester provide their related `Ledger Access Token` in order to acquire the token for the target party.

item.description:
Start the Marketplace in Daml Hub by either :

1. Starting the "DA Marketplace" via the Arcade in hub.daml.com;
2. Create a new Project and Ledger on Daml Hub, pull the Marketplace repo [(here)](https://github.com/digital-asset/da-marketplace), then upload the generated `dit` file generated after running the `make package` command.

For more API's provided by Daml Hub, see the official Daml Hub API Documentation [here](https://hub.daml.com/docs/api).

Note - Actual tokens have been removed from requests and responses and replaced with `<<REMOVED>>` for security reasons.

item.name: Marketplace
Operator
Role
Offers

request.description: Offer the Custody role to a party.
Offer the Exchange (or Trading) role to a party.
Offer the Regulator role to a party.
Offer the Distributor (or Agent House) role to a party.
Offer the Exchange Clearing role to a party.
Offer a party to provide trade Matching services.
Offer a party to provide Settlement services.

item.description:
An Operator can offer parties to be providers of certain services or roles.

The Provider has the choice to either `Accept` or `Decline` the offer from the Operator.

item.name: Approve Requests

request.description: Approve a request from a party to have the Custody role.
Approve a request from a party to have the Exchange role.
Approve a request from a party to have the Regulator role.
Approve a request from a party to have the Distributor role.
Approve a request from a party to have the Clearing role.
Approve a request from a party to provide Matching services.
Approve a request from a party to provide Settlement services.

item.description: Parties can make requests to be a provider of certain services or roles. An Operator can approve a request from a party.

request.description: Creates an `Operator.Role` contract which allows an Operator to offer certain roles to other parties and to accept requests to provide services.

item.description: The Operator Role is a special contract which allows an Operator of a market to manage certain services or roles parties can provide.

item.name: Regulator
Role

request.description: Accept a Regulator role offer from an Operator.
As a provider, request the Regulator role from the Operator of a Marketplace.
Offer Regulator services to a customer.
Approve a request from a customer for Regulator services.
TODO: fails due to missing signature.

response.name: Terminate Regulator Service

request.description: Terminates the role contract of a Regulator provider.

item.description: A Regulator `Role` allows a party to be a provider of KYC services to other parties in the network.

item.name: Service

request.description: Accept a Regulator service offer.
Request Regulator services from a provider.
Request a provider to verify your Identity (aka KYC) on the network.
Verify a parties identity on the network.

item.description: A customer having a Regulator `Service` allows them to make a request to verify their identity. The provider of this service can then approve that they have KYC'd the customer which creates a verified identity contract on the ledger
A Regulator facilitates KYC (Know Your Customer) to parties on the network.

Role

item.description: Make `Offer`s to parties or accept `Request`s from parties for Custody and Issuance services.

request.description: Accept the Custody offer from a provider.
Request Custody services from a provider.
Request to open an account. A customer makes this request and then the service provider can either approve to reject the request.

Request to open an allocation account. 

Allocation accounts are required for certain services where collateral from the customer needs to be "locked". For example, to cover a trade in a collateralized market or a bid in a Primary Distribution of an asset.
Request to close an account.

Request to credit an account with an asset.

A customer makes a request to credit their account with an asset and the Custody provider asserts the request and approves/rejects as appropriate.
A client request to debit their account.
A customer request to transfer assets to another party.
Approve the request from a customer to open an account.
Approve the request from a customer to open an allocation account.
Approve the request from a customer to close an account.
Approve the request from a customer to close an allocation account.
Approve a customer request to credit their account.
Approve a customer request to debit their account.
Approve a customer request to transfer an asset from their account to another account.
Approve a customer request to lifecycle their asset.

item.description: Create various Accounts, facilitate the crediting, debiting and transferring of asset. Process the lifecycle event against assets.

item.name: Issuance

request.description: Accept a service offer for Issuance.
Request Issuance services from a provider.
Request to issue a new Asset on the network.
Request to make an issuance of an asset to an account of a specific quantity.

Request to reduce the size of an asset which has already been issued.

The `issuanceId` is the identifier of the previous issuance to reduce.
Approve the request to create an asset.
Approve an issuance request.
Approve a request to reduce the issuance of an asset.

item.description: Create new assets, issue units or remove units from the network

request.description: Accept an offer of Listing services.
Request Listing services from a provider.
A request to List an asset for trading purposes.

Approve a request to create a new listing.

In most scenario's, this choice will be triggered by the exchange provider upon successfully creating a listing on their exchange.

A request to disable a Listing.

The listing will still exist, but its status will change to disabled.
Approve a request to disable a listed asset.

item.name: Settlement

request.description: Accept an offer for Settlement services.
Request for Settlement services from a provider.

Settle a settlement instruction.

In most scenario's, this will be called by the system either in real-time due to receiving an event (such as a trade confirmation) or as part of a batch settlement process.
Removes the ability of the provider to provide Settlement services.

item.description: Provide and facilitate settlements between parties on the network.

item.name: Distribution

request.description: Accept a role offer for Primary Distribution.
Request for a Primary Distribution role.
Create an offer to provide Auction services to a customer.
Create an offer to provide Bidding services to a customer.
Approve a request from a customer to provide Auction services.
Approve a request from a customer to provide Bidding services.

response.name: Terminate Auction service

request.description: TODO: fails due to missing signature.

response.name: Terminate Bidding service

request.description: Terminate the role contract of a Primary Distribution provider.

Accept an offer for Auction services.

The request requires the customer provide their trading, allocation and receivable account.

Request for auction services from a Primary Distribution provider.

Requires the customer to provide their trading, allocation and receivable account.
A request for the Primary Distribution of an Asset.
Cancel the request for the Primary Distribution of an asset.
Approve a Primary Distribution request from a customer.
Reject a Primary Distribution request from a customer.

Process an auction.

This will update all bids accordingly and generate the settlement instructions for 
all successfully bidders.

Accept an offer for bidding services.

Customer must provider their trading and allocation accounts.

Request bidding services from a Primary Distribution provider.

Customer must provider their trading and allocation accounts.

Submit a bid against an auctioned asset.

Setting `allowPublishing` will allow subsequent invited investors to the auction to view party whom submitted the bid plus the quantity. The bid price is not shared with other investors.

response.name: Submit Bid - Deposit does not cover submitted bid

request.description:
Request (or invite) an investor to take part in a Primary Distribution of an asset.

If a lead bid has already been submitted (or other bidders have allowed the publishing of their bid), the requested party will see the party whom make the bid and their bid quantity. The bid price is not shared.

item.description: Primary Distribution of assets to selected investors. Issuer's of assets can create auctions and the auction provider invites investors to bid on the said asset. Auctions are processed using a `Dutch Auction`, where the final price is determined ordering bids from highest to lowest and taking the lowest successful bid. See [here](https://www.investopedia.com/terms/d/dutchauction.asp) for more information.

item.name: Clearing

request.description: Accept a Clearing role offer.
Request to have a Clearing role as a provider.

item.description: Clearing APIs are subject to major change and thus aren't documented.

The Marketplace application provides a set of services which allows for creating a bespoke market, specific to the market requirements.

Each business domain has its own set of Service's. A Service may either be offered to a customer or a customer can request services from a provider.

Role contracts allow for managing which services parties are allowed to provide.

Authorization for a request is specified in the `Authorization` section of a given request and can be one of the following parties: 
- Operator (OperatorToken)
- Provider (ProviderToken)
- Customer (CustomerToken)

The authorization tokens used in the examples were generated for use with a locally running ledger sandbox. With the default local setup running, these tokens can be re-used.

When exercising requests which have choices, if the said request has a key it will be documented as such even thought it can also be identified by its contract identifier. If a request has a contract identifier, then there is no such key available to identify the contract.
